baseline.description: UK economy recovering from multiple shocks; living standards under pressure with RHDI per head below pre-pandemic peak

metrics.label: RHDI per head index
metrics.note: Comparative G7 measure — target is highest sustained growth, not a specific numeric target

target.description: Raise living standards in every part of the UK, with the highest sustained growth in the G7
target.note: Comparative target — no single numeric threshold; measured via RHDI per head, GDP per capita, and regional GDP per head

requiredTrajectory.description: UK GDP growth must consistently exceed other G7 economies (US, Japan, Germany, France, Italy, Canada) over the parliament
requiredTrajectory.note: Depends on relative G7 performance — sustained outperformance required rather than a fixed annual rate

theoryOfChange: Economic stability combined with investment in infrastructure, planning reform, industrial strategy, skills, trade, innovation and the net zero transition will unlock private investment and raise productivity, leading to sustained growth that outpaces G7 peers and raises living standards across all UK regions.

deliverables.commitment: National Wealth Fund to crowd in up to £70bn private investment

baseline.description: England building approximately 220,000-240,000 net additional dwellings per year, well below the 300,000/yr rate needed

target.description: Build 1.5 million new homes in England and fast-track planning decisions on at least 150 major infrastructure projects
target.note: Cumulative over 5-year parliament; also 150 infrastructure planning decisions

requiredTrajectory.description: 300,000 net additional dwellings per year on average, with the document noting a significant ramp-up expected in year 3 of parliament as planning reforms take effect
requiredTrajectory.note: Front-loaded policy reforms expected to yield results from ~2027 onwards

theoryOfChange: Mandatory housing targets through the revised NPPF and the Planning and Infrastructure Bill remove the binding constraint on housebuilding. Combined with £3.1bn affordable homes funding, new towns, infrastructure acceleration, and construction workforce expansion, housing supply can scale to 300,000 homes per year.

deliverables.commitment: Publish revised NPPF with mandatory housing targets
Update National Policy Statements for major infrastructure
£500M additional Affordable Homes Programme funding (£3.1bn total per year)

baseline.description: 7.6 million people on the NHS waiting list, with over 3 million waiting more than 18 weeks for treatment (September 2024)

target.description: Meet the NHS standard of 92% of patients waiting no longer than 18 weeks from referral to treatment
target.note: NHS constitutional standard; requires clearing millions from the backlog

requiredTrajectory.description: From approximately 57% within 18 weeks to 92%, requiring roughly 7 percentage points improvement per year, plus 2 million additional operations, scans and appointments annually (40,000 per week)
requiredTrajectory.note: ~7 percentage points per year; 40,000 additional appointments per week above current levels

mission: Get the NHS back on its feet
theoryOfChange: Immediate capacity expansion through 40,000 extra appointments per week reduces the backlog. Structural reforms — shifting care from hospitals to the community, from analogue to digital systems, and from treating sickness to prevention — sustainably reduce demand growth and increase throughput. The 10-Year Health Plan provides the reform blueprint.

deliverables.commitment: Deliver 2 million additional operations, scans and appointments per year (40,000 per week)
Three reform shifts: hospital to community, analogue to digital, sickness to prevention

baseline.description: Neighbourhood policing significantly depleted after years of cuts; neighbourhood officer numbers at historic lows

metrics.label: Police workforce (FTE)
metrics.note: Baseline neighbourhood policing numbers to be precisely established; overall police workforce data tracked via Home Office statistics

target.description: Put 13,000 additional police officers, PCSOs and special constables into neighbourhood policing roles
target.note: Net additional to neighbourhood policing specifically

requiredTrajectory.description: Approximately 2,600 additional neighbourhood officers per year across the parliament, requiring sustained recruitment, training and redeployment

theoryOfChange: The Neighbourhood Policing Guarantee provides the mandate and funding model for dedicated neighbourhood officers. Named contactable officers per neighbourhood rebuild public trust. A new career pathway attracts and retains recruits. Respect Orders and the Police Performance Unit ensure antisocial behaviour outcomes improve alongside officer numbers.

deliverables.commitment: Named, contactable officer for every neighbourhood
Establish Police and Crime Performance Unit
New career pathway for neighbourhood policing
Introduce Respect Orders for antisocial behaviour

baseline.description: 67.7% of five-year-olds achieving a good level of development on the Early Years Foundation Stage (EYFS) profile

metrics.label: Additional children needed per year
metrics.note: 40,000-45,000 additional children per year need to reach GLD

target.description: 75% of five-year-olds in England school-ready, as measured by the EYFS good level of development
target.note: Requires 40,000-45,000 additional children per year reaching good level of development

requiredTrajectory.description: From 67.7% to 75% by 2028 requires roughly 1.8 percentage points improvement per year over 4 years, equivalent to 40,000-45,000 additional children reaching the threshold annually
requiredTrajectory.note: ~1.8pp per year; 40,000-45,000 additional children reaching GLD each year

theoryOfChange: Expanding funded childcare hours and building 3,000 school-based nurseries increases access to quality early education for disadvantaged children. Recruiting 6,500 extra teachers reduces ratios. Family Hubs and Start for Life, combined with evidence-based early literacy programmes, support the most disadvantaged children and lift the overall EYFS pass rate to 75%.

deliverables.commitment: Expand to 30 funded childcare hours for working parents
Expand Family Hubs and Start for Life programme

baseline.description: UK generating approximately 55-60% of electricity from clean sources (renewables plus nuclear), varying by quarter

metrics.label: % electricity from clean sources
metrics.note: Varies quarterly; includes renewables + nuclear. Approximately 55-60% in recent periods

target.description: Generate at least 95% of electricity from clean power by 2030
target.note: Clean = renewables + nuclear; requires near-complete decarbonisation of electricity generation

requiredTrajectory.description: From approximately 57% clean power to 95% by 2030 requires roughly 6-7 percentage points improvement per year, driven by massive expansion of offshore wind, solar, and grid infrastructure
requiredTrajectory.note: Massive acceleration of renewable capacity build-out and grid modernisation needed

mission: Make Britain a clean energy superpower
theoryOfChange: Great British Energy provides public investment vehicle. Lifting the onshore wind ban and record renewables auction rounds accelerate deployment. Planning reform for energy infrastructure and grid building removes bottlenecks. £21.7bn carbon capture investment and the Warm Homes Plan reduce reliance on fossil fuels. The Clean Power 2030 Action Plan provides the detailed delivery pathway.

deliverables.commitment: Establish Great British Energy (headquarters in Aberdeen)
Planning reform for energy infrastructure and grid building
Warm Homes Plan for energy efficiency
